questions.question: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy?

options.B: Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

questions.explanation: During a normal pregnancy, the vaginal epithelium undergoes changes, including increased glycogen metabolism, which helps to support the growth of Lactobacilli and maintain a healthy vaginal environment.

questions.question: In pregnancy, vaginal cytology shows a predominance of
questions.explanation: During pregnancy, vaginal cytology shows a predominance of intermediate cells.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman has come for pre-conceptional counselling. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2 and she is worried about weight gain during pregnancy. How much weight should she gain during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: The patient in the given question is obese. The recommended gestational weight gain in such a patient is 5-9 kg. Ideally, weight gain should depend on the pre-pregnancy BMI (body mass index) level. The gestational weight gain recommended for each BMI category by the Institute of Medicine (IOM) are as follows: Category - BMI (in kg/m2) - Recommended weight gain: Underweight <18.5 - 12.5-18 kg, Normal 18.5-24.9 - 11.5-14 kg, Overweight 25-29.9 - 7-11.5 kg, Obese >30 - 5-9.1 kg.

questions.question: In pregnancy, the diaphragm is elevated by
questions.explanation: The diaphragm is elevated by 4 cm in pregnancy. The anatomical changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy are: • Elevation of diaphragm by 4 cm • Transverse diameter of chest increases by 2 cm • Chest circumference increases by 5-7 cm • Subcostal angle increases from 68 degrees to 103 degrees

questions.question: A pregnant woman at her 30th week of pregnancy undergoes a pulmonary function test. Provided there is no respiratory abnormality, which of the following would be decreased?
questions.explanation: Functional residual capacity decreases in pregnancy. The changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy are: (Mnemonic: TIMM increases in pregnancy) Increase - Tidal volume, Inspiratory capacity, Minute O2 uptake, Minute ventilation. Decrease - Functional residual capacity, Expiratory reserve volume, Residual volume. Total lung capacity is slightly decreased. Unaffected - Respiratory rate, Vital capacity, Inspiratory reserve volume. Lung volumes and Capacities: Maximum inspiration - Tidal Volume (TV), Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), Functional residual capacity (FRC), Vital Capacity (VC), Inspiratory capacity (IC), Expiratory reserve volume (ERV), Residual volume (RV).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about prolactin levels in pregnancy?

options.A: Lowest in pregnancy and increases after delivery
options.B: Highest at term and reduces after delivery
options.C: Increases during pregnancy and plateaus during lactation

questions.explanation: The maternal plasma prolactin level is highest at term and reduces after delivery. Despite this high level, milk secretion does not occur during pregnancy due to the action of estrogen and progesterone. Prolactin secretion returns to the nonpregnant level a few weeks after delivery. The levels of estrogen and progesterone fall, and hence, prolactin can promote milk secretion even at a lesser concentration.

questions.question: Which of the following produce estrogen and progesterone in the first two months of pregnancy?
questions.explanation: In the first two months of pregnancy, estrogen and progesterone are produced by the corpus luteum. It functions maximally during the second month of pregnancy and thereafter contributes relatively little. Estrogen is synthesized in the placenta from the 7th week and progesterone from the 8th week.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents to an antenatal clinic for the first time during the second trimester. In view of a family history of thyroid disorders, a thyroid function test is sent for. Altered levels of which of the following would not be a cause for concern?
questions.explanation: Total T3 levels are altered throughout pregnancy. Total T3 and total T4 increase due to stimulation of thyroid tissue by hCG during the early period of gestation. However, there is no change in free T3 and T4 due to an increase in thyroid-binding globulin (TBG). This leads to a transient fall in TSH during the early weeks of gestation. The level of TSH becomes normal during the second and third trimester. Hormone secretion during pregnancy: • Increased: GH, insulin, prolactin, aldosterone, testosterone, total T3, T4 • Decreased: LH, FSH, DHEAS (dihydroepiandrosterone) • Unchanged: TSH, ADH (vasopressin), free T3, T4

questions.question: Which of the following do not synthesise relaxin during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Relaxin is not synthesised by the fetal adrenal gland in a pregnant woman. It is synthesised by the corpus luteum, decidua, and placenta. Relaxin is a placental protein hormone. Plasma levels peak between 8 and 12 weeks of gestation and decline thereafter to lower levels that persist until term. Functions of relaxin are: • Relaxation of myometrium and quiescence of early pregnancy • Enhancement of the glomerular filtration rate • Endometrial vascular remodelling by inducing secretion of VEGF

questions.question: Which among the given features is not a major physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Among the given features, hypothyroidism is not a major physiological change in pregnancy. The beta-subunits of hCG and TSH are identical. An increase in hCG during pregnancy stimulates the thyroid and leads to a decrease in TSH levels. The thyroid undergoes enlargement and boosts the production of hormones. This is accompanied by increased production of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG). All these changes increase total T4 and T3 in the first trimester. But the physiologically important free T4 and T3 levels remain unchanged. Hence, physiologically pregnant women remain euthyroid. Option A: Normal pregnancy is characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. Human placental lactogen (hPL) secreted during pregnancy helps in adaptation to fetal energy requirements. Insulin resistance causes prolonged hyperglycemia and glucose flow to the fetus. It also favors protein synthesis. To counterbalance the increased insulin resistance and prevent maternal hyperglycemia, maternal insulin levels are increased. Option B: By the 3rd trimester, there is an increase in the maternal basal metabolic rate by 10 to 20% in comparison to a nonpregnant woman. Option D: During normal pregnancy, mean arterial pressure and vascular resistance decrease, while blood volume and cardiac output rate increase. This helps in meeting metabolic demands of the enlarged uterus, providing nutrients to the rapidly growing placenta and fetus, and safeguarding the mother against the effects of parturition-associated blood loss.

questions.question: A pregnant woman with diabetes mellitus is advised to increase her insulin dose as pregnancy is characterized by insulin resistance. Which of the following is not implicated in this phenomenon?
questions.explanation: hCG is not implicated in insulin resistance during pregnancy. As the fetus is dependent on maternal glucose for sustenance, the blood glucose levels are maintained at a high level in the mother. In response to this, the insulin level in the mother increases, which reduces the maternal blood glucose. To counteract this, the placenta secretes certain hormones which increase insulin resistance in the mother. This resistance is maximal between 24 to 28 weeks. Hormones increasing insulin resistance include: • Human placental lactogen - Increases lipolysis and liberation of free fatty acids • Progesterone and estrogen. Placental growth hormone - Major determinant of maternal insulin resistance after mid-pregnancy • Cortisol • Prolactin

questions.question: Which of the following changes are not seen in the renal system during pregnancy?112
questions.explanation: Serum creatinine levels decrease during normal pregnancy from a mean of 0.7 mg/dL to 0.5mg/dL.Physiological changes in the renal system during pregnancy include:• Increase in:• Renal blood flow(+80%)•GFR(+50%)• Creatinine clearance• Glucosuria•• Decrease in:• Plasma osmolality• Creatinine•• Uric acid• Na/K/ClAnatomical changes in the renal system during pregnancy include:•⚫ Both kidneys enlarge by 1 cm• Hydroureter and hydronephrosis - More common on the right side due to dextrorotation of theuterus• Congestion of the bladder causing decreased bladder capacity• Increased bladder pressure and intraurethral pressure121

questions.question: Which of the following is increased during pregnancy?

options.C: Total oxygen carrying capacity of blood

questions.explanation: The total oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood increases during pregnancy.During pregnancy, there is an increase in total haemoglobin (Hb) resulting in increased totaloxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. However, there is a relative decrease in Hb.concentration (hematocrit) due to a greater increase in plasma volume. This decreasesoxygen-carrying capacity per unit volume of blood.Maternal iron stores are not sufficient to meet the increased demand during pregnancy and hencethe serum iron and ferritin concentration falls.The plasma volume expansion also lowers serum potassium.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Decrease in peripheral vascular resistance is a physiological change seen in pregnancy.Cardiovascular parameters that increase in pregnancy are:• Cardiac output• Stroke volume•• Heart rateCardiovascular parameters that decrease in pregnancy are:••Peripheral vascular resistance (due to smooth muscle relaxation by progesterone)• Both diastolic BP and systolic BP (decrease in DBP > SBP)•Mean arterial BP• Artery venous O2 gradient

questions.question: A primigravida presents in the 2nd trimester complaining that her slippers do not fitanymore. On examination, her pulse is 88/min and blood pressure is 130/84mm Hg. You notebilateral pitting edema up to the level of ankles. What would you advise her?
questions.explanation: The clinical features are suggestive of physiological edema during pregnancy for which the mostappropriate treatment is bed rest.It occurs due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressingon the common iliac veins.Features of physiological edema in pregnancy are:•Slight degree of ankle edema• Usually confined to one leg, more commonly the right leg•• Not associated with any other features of preeclampsia (like BP>140/90mm Hg, proteinuria)• Disappears with rest• Other cardiac, renal and hematological pathologies are absent122

questions.question: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen during pregnancy?113

options.A: Pulmonary blood flow is increased by 2,500 mL/min
options.B: Blood flow to the skin decreases to 300 mL/min
options.C: Blood flow to the uterus increases to 750 mL/min
options.D: Renal blood flow increases by 400 mL/min

questions.explanation: The blood flow to the skin and mucous membranes increases during pregnancy to a maximum of500 mL/min by the 36th week. Symptoms experienced during pregnancy such as increased heatsensation, sweating or having a stuffy nose can be explained by the increased blood flow.Regional distribution of blood flow during pregnancy:• Uterine blood flow - increased from 50 mL/min in the non-pregnant state to about 750 mL nearterm.• Pulmonary blood flow - increased by 2,500 mL/min.•Renal blood flow - increases by 400 mL/min at 16th week and remains at this level till term.

questions.question: A 23-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 30 weeks of gestation. During examination, which of the following cardiovascular findings would not be a cause for alarm?
questions.explanation: S3 is normally heard during pregnancy. The third heart sound (S3) occurs due to rapid diastolic filling in hypervolemic states such as pregnancy, anemia, or thyrotoxicosis. Hypervolemia is a normal physiological change during pregnancy. The auscultation of a fixed split S2, fourth heart sound (S4), or a pericardial knock are suggestive of cardiac pathology.

questions.question: Which of the following coagulation factors are increased in pregnancy?
questions.explanation: All clotting factors increase in pregnancy except factors XI and XIII.Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state with physiological changes such as:••All clotting factors are increased (except factors XI and XIII)• Fibrinogen levels are also increased•The viscosity of blood decreases due to hemodilution•Clotting time and bleeding time is unaffectedThe most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestationalthrombocytopenia. This is due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and thewomen are generally asymptomatic.

questions.question: A 24-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks of gestation presents to the antenatal clinic withcomplaints of dizziness on lying down for the past one week. She feels better on sitting up orturning to the side. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: 123The clinical features are suggestive of supine hypotension syndrome due to inferior vena cavalcompression.During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the inferior vena cava(IVC) when the patient is in the supine position. To compensate, there will be an opening up ofthe collaterals of paravertebral and azygous veins.When collaterals fail to open, venous return of the heart is reduced leading to hypotension,tachycardia, and syncope. The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patientto lateral position.

questions.question: 114Which of the following is true regarding the sensitivity of uterine musculature?

options.C: Enhanced by both estrogen and progesterone
options.D: Enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone

questions.explanation: The sensitivity of uterine musculature is enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone.Estrogen stimulates the synthesis of myometrial contractile proteins through cAMP. Thisincreases the excitability of uterine muscles and the frequency of action potentials.Progesterone decreases the frequency and intensity of uterine contractions. This helps to preventthe expulsion of the implanted ovum. However, it increases the amplitude of contraction.

questions.question: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest her to relieve the pain?

options.C: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
options.D: Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.explanation: Extension at the knee joint and dorsiflexion at the ankle joint helps in stretching the calf muscleswhich relieves the pain.Leg cramps are minor ailments during pregnancy mostly due to a deficiency of diffusible serumcalcium or elevation of serum phosphorus. Management includes massaging the leg, stretchingexercises, application of local heat, and supplementation of vitamin B1 and calcium.

questions.question: Theca lutein cysts are not associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Theca lutein cysts are not seen in hyperprolactinemia.Theca-lutein cysts are benign ovarian lesions resulting from exaggerated physiological folliclestimulation. They are usually associated with markedly elevated serum levels of hCG.Theca lutein cysts are found in association with:•• Large placenta• Diabetes•Anti-D alloimmunization• Multifetal gestations• Fetal hydrops• Gestational trophoblastic disease - Molar pregnancy124• Reduced hCG clearance - Chronic renal failureThey may also be found in normal pregnancy due to an exaggerated response of the ovaries tonormal circulating levels of hCG.

questions.question: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) occurs most commonly in the third trimester or earlypostpartum period.Risk factors include Pre-eclampsia/HELLP syndrome, male fetus, previous history of AFLP, andmultiple gestations.AFLP (acute yellow atrophy or acute fatty metamorphosis) is the most common cause of acuteliver failure in pregnancy. It usually occurs in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly inthe third trimester. It occurs due to fetal deficiency of long-chain acyl-coenzyme Adehydrogenase (LCHAD) or poor placental mitochondrial function.The patients present with persistent nausea and vomiting, progressive jaundice, and epigastricpain. Features like acute hemolysis, hypoglycemia, hypertension, proteinuria, thrombocytopenia,and edema can also be present. Symptoms may progress to fulminant hepatic failure withencephalopathy, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. Hypofibrinogenemia,hypocholesterolemia, and prolonged clotting time can be seen. An elevated d-dimer isseen. Microscopy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. A trial of labor byinduction or delivery by Cesarean is done. Intensive supportive measures including bloodtransfusion should be provided.The clinical and laboratory findings of acute liver diseases in pregnancy are as follows:The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. Appropriatemanagement is immediate termination of pregnancy irrespective of gestational age by inductionor delivery by Cesarean (for obstetric reasons) is done. Intensive supportive measures includingblood transfusion should be provided.DisordersHELLP syndromeOnset in pregnancMid to lateLateObstetric cholestasisAcute fatty liver of pregnancyLateViral hepatitisVariableyDifferentiating feaEpigastric pain, hypertPrurituselevateddirectturesension, elevatedindirectbilirubinSigns ofliver failurelikehypoglycemiaFeverbilirubinAST (U/L)≤300≤200200-8002000+Bilirubin (mg/dL)1-41-54-105-20Platelets↓↓Normal↓↓↓FibrinogenNormalNormal↓↓↓Normal125DisordersHELLP syndromeObstetric cholestasisAcute fatty liver of pregnancyViral hepatitisD-dimer↑Normal↑NormalProthrombin timeNormalNormal↑↑↑Hemolysis↑↑No↑↑↑No

questions.question: What does the term 'placental sign' denote?115

options.A: Alteration of fetal heart rate on pressing the head into the pelvis
options.B: Spotting on the expected date of period in early months of pregnancy
options.C: Permanent lengthening of the cord in 3rd stage of labor
options.D: Slight gush of bleeding in 3rd stage of laborCorrect Option

questions.explanation: Spotting on the expected date of menstruation in the early months of pregnancy is known asplacental sign.Cyclic bleeding may occur up to 12 weeks of pregnancy until the decidual space is obliterated bythe fusion of decidua parietalis with decidua capsularis. The bleeding is usually scanty and lastsfor a shorter duration than in a regular menstrual cycle.Option A: Slowing of the fetal heart rate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis issuggestive of placenta previa (especially of posterior type) and is called Stallworthy's sign. Thefetal heart rate recovers as soon as the pressure is released.Options C and D: Permanent lengthening of the cord and slight gush of bleeding in 3rd stage oflabor are suggestive of separation of the placenta.126

options.A: . It metabolizes the glycogenstores and causes an increased production of lactic acid.
